A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
SASKATOON, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name ____________________________
   Thomas Taylor

2. Your address _____________________________
   Candiac SASK

3. Date ___________________________________
   Dec. 12, 1962

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) ____________________________
   Parkhill Ontario Steven County

5. What was your father's name and occupation? ________________________________
   Robert Taylor Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) ______________________
   May 1882

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Ontario Middlesex County and Steven County 1854 to 1882

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
   27 and 28

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   In 1881 I brought a car load of horses to Emerson Man, for Shoalts and Morrison Railroad contractors.
   In 1882 I bought more horses to them and also worked as teamster and in charge of hauling feed for the railroad between Brandon and Gie Apple.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    Mostly by reading and government information and my connection with Shoalts and Morrison supplying horses.
1. Your full name: Thomas Taylor
2. Your address: Camclaire, SASK,
3. Date: Dec. 12, 1962
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Parkhill Ontario
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Robert Taylor, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May, 1882
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - Ontario
   - Middlesex County and Steven County 1854 & 1882
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - In 1881 I brought a car load of horses & Emerson Irons, for Sharts & Moravian Railroad construction.
   - In 1882 I brought more horses to those already worked on Seaman and in charge of hauling feed for the railroad between Brandon and Galtville.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    - Primarily by reading and government information and my connection with Sharts and Moravian supplies for horses.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They entertained some doubts regarding my decision.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   On a freight train to Emerson in 1881, to Winnipeg in 1882.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Horses and wagon from Brandon.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   Adventures and excitement consisted mostly of driving hay and grain to the construction camps on the rail road. Crossing creeks, rivers and sloughs where no road existed. Getting stuck looking and reloading hay at sloughs and creeks often waist deep in water for hours at a time.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Wolf Creek, Assiniboia, New Wolseley, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   In August 1882.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   In 1890 I returned to Parkhill, Ontario and remained there until Oct. 1899. I then returned to Wolseley, Sask., and lived on my Homestead until 1937.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Farming, cattle dealing, and butchering. Farming.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They encouraged me to make my decision.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
    On a freight train to Edmonton, Alberta in 1881.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
    Horse and wagon from Brandon.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
    Adventure and excitement. Quality of chewing hay and grain to the construction camps on the rail road. Crossing creeks, rivers and always where we could exist. Getting stuck looking out at always and weeks after we were deep in water for hours at a time.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
    Wolf Creek, Assiniboia. New Wabamun 800 ft

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
    In August 1882

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
    In 1890 I returned to Parkhill, Ontario and remained there until Oct. 1899. Then returned to Wolseley 800 ft and lived on my homestead until 1937.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
    Farming. Cattle dealing and butchering. Farming
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Sarah Cody Puffer, 17th March 1893
at Rebecca, West Missouri, Middlesex County, Ontario

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Yes.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

Two brothers and three sisters between 1886 and 1890.
One sister and one brother lived their lives out south of Wabasey, Sask. 2 sisters married and lived at Elkhorn Man.
1 brother was accidentally shot in 1889. My parents came West with me in 1899.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

On two occasions I had encounters with Indians but nothing serious developed. My brother and I shot and killed what is believed to be the last Buffalo seen in this area in 1885. I was also one of the first Councilors and Chairman of the Council of Local Improvement District 8-E-2 in Assin.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Most travel was by horse and wagon or democrat. Attending church, visiting, and attending meetings. I visited back in Ontario on six occasions by train.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.? How often? How far? By what means of travel?
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1907 and 8

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Wolsley, 14 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   In 1907 the C.N.R. was built from Brandon to Regina and the towns of Glenavon, Carleton, and Morentmoore came into being. Roads building started about 1902 replacing prairie trails.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Not regular.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   About 1900 those closer to Wolsley went to town fairly quite regular on Saturdays.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Some clothes but not much of anything.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1911
   Abbottsford Rural Telephone Co Ltd.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Undecided until 1899
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1907 and 8.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

In 1907 the CPR was built from Brandon to Regina and the town of Glenboro, Caribou, and Homestead came into being. Road building started about 1909.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? About twice a week.

30. When did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

About 1900 those closer to Wolseley went to town fairly quite regularly on Saturdays.

31. When did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

Some clothes but not much of anything.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

Alberta Rural Telephone Co. Ltd.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Unclear until 1899.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
   Several families.
   Some acquired land closer to market and others left for financial reasons.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
   Not many
   Our family

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
   I held office as councillor for my division from 1900 to 1915. Also, was a member of the local telephone board during organization and several years after. I was also connected with Saskatchewan Grain Growers Association and M.G.A. from these organizations until about 1920.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
   My brother and I owned the first threshing outfit in our district. It was a case separator, hand feed and straw cannon driven by a horsepower.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
   Greenville School District No. 86, got its name in honor of the first large family to settle in the district, Mr. Tom Green. The district was formed in 1886.
   Moffat Post Office was named in honor of Dr. J.E. Moffat, who owned land in the district about 1884.
   Candia was first named Taylor siding, but later changed to Candia because the name conflicted with another post office.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some acquired land along to market and others left for financial reasons.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

Out family

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I held office as Councilman for Grey Township from 1900 to 1915. Also, was a member of the Great Western Road during organization and several years after. I was also connected with Sack-Green Gurney Co., Ltd. & Co., from their formation about 1920.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My brother and I owned the first threshing outfit in our district; got into a case together. Harold and Elmo Gurney clipped by a horsepower.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Greenville School District No. 86 - got its name in honor of the first large family to settle in the district - Big West Green. The district was formed in 1886.

Moffat Post Office was named in honor of Dr. J.E. Moffat who moved there in the district about 1889.

Carbine was first named Taylor's Mill, but later changed to Carbine because the name conflicted with another post office.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Two sons, R.D. Taylor, Wolseley SASK., retired,
W.D. Taylor, Cardiac, SASK.

Also eleven grand children.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

1. The change from oxen to horses, then to tractors,
2. From prairie trails to roads, and highways,
3. The changes in farm machinery, from walking plows and wagons to combines, trucks, and big machinery,
4. The change from driving or walking to the Rural School to the School Buses of today.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.
